company.name: Quality Terminal Services, LLC
company.address: 252 Clayton Street, Fourth Floor, Denver, Colorado 80206
company.business_description: Quality Terminal Services, LLC provides transportation services on a contract basis to railroads, including Burlington Northern Santa Fe (BNSF) and Union Pacific (UP), with some of its employees working on the properties of these railroads.

case_info.legal_authority: Section 621(a) of the Fair Credit Reporting Act, 15 U.S.C. § 1681s(a); Section 5(a) of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 45(a)

complaint.factual_background: Quality Terminal Services, LLC (QTS), a Colorado company providing transportation services to BNSF and Union Pacific railroads, was required beginning in March 2007 to conduct background checks on all employees and job applicants using the e-RAILSAFE system. When applicants failed these checks, QTS denied them employment — constituting adverse action under the FCRA — but failed to provide the legally required pre-adverse action notices (including a copy of the consumer report and Summary of Consumer Rights) to approximately 53 applicants before taking action. Additionally, in 42 of those cases, QTS failed to provide proper post-adverse action notices containing the required information about the consumer reporting agency and the applicant's dispute rights. These failures were knowing and constituted a pattern or practice of FCRA violations.

representations_made.description: QTS took adverse action against 53 job applicants based on their background checks without providing pre-adverse action notices as required by FCRA Section 604(b)(3)
representations_made.quoted_text: 15. From at least March 2007 through April 2008, QTS took adverse action against 53 job applicants by denying employment to them, based in whole or in part on information found in their background checks. In each of these cases, QTS failed to provide a pre-adverse action notice to the applicant, as is required by Section 604(b)(3) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681b(b)(3). In addition, in 42 of these cases, the adverse action notices that QTS provided to the applicants did not contain any of the information required by Section 615(a) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681m(a).

representations_made.description: In 42 of the 53 adverse action cases, QTS failed to provide adverse action notices containing any of the information required by FCRA Section 615(a)
representations_made.quoted_text: In addition, in 42 of these cases, the adverse action notices that QTS provided to the applicants did not contain any of the information required by Section 615(a) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681m(a).

counts.title: Failure to Provide Pre-Adverse Action Notices
counts.representation: From at least March 2007 until April 2008, QTS took adverse action against approximately 53 job applicants based in whole or in part on their consumer reports without providing pre-adverse action notices (including a copy of the consumer report and the Summary of Consumer Rights) prior to taking action.
counts.fact: Section 604(b)(3) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681b(b)(3), requires that any person who uses a consumer report for employment purposes and takes adverse action must first provide the individual with a copy of the consumer report and the Summary of Consumer Rights Under the FCRA before taking the adverse action.
counts.conclusion: By and through these acts and practices, Defendant violated Section 604(b)(3) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681b(b)(3).

counts.title: Failure to Provide Post-Adverse Action Notices
counts.representation: From at least March 2007 until April 2008, QTS took adverse action against approximately 42 job applicants based in whole or in part on their consumer reports without providing proper adverse action notices after taking the action.
counts.fact: Section 615(a) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681m(a), requires that after taking adverse action based on a consumer report, the user must notify the individual of: (1) the name, address, and telephone number of the CRA; (2) a statement that the CRA did not make the adverse action decision; (3) the right to obtain a free copy of the report within 60 days; and (4) the right to dispute the accuracy or completeness of the report.
counts.conclusion: By and through these acts and practices, Defendant violated Section 615(a) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681m(a).

definitions.Adverse action, consumer, consumer repor: mean the terms as defined in Section 603 of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C.§ 1681a, as amended.
definitions.Defendant: Quality Terminal Services, LLC, and its successors and assigns.
definitions.Commerce: as defined in Section 4 of the Federal Trade Commission Act, 15 U.S.C. § 44.

provisions.title: Civil Penalty
provisions.summary: Defendant must pay a civil penalty of $53,000 to the United States within ten business days of entry of the Order, with provisions for default interest and non-dischargeability in bankruptcy.

requirements.description: Defendant shall pay a civil penalty of $53,000 via electronic fund transfer or cashier's check within ten (10) business days of entry of the Order.
requirements.quoted_text: A. Defendant shall make the payment required by Paragraph I within ten (10) business days of the date of entry of this Order by electronic fund transfer or cashier’s check in accordance with the instructions provided by the Office of Consumer Litigation, Civil Division, U.S. Department of Justice, Washington, D.C. 20530, for appropriate disposition;

requirements.description: In the event of default in payment continuing for ten (10) business days beyond the due date, the entire unpaid penalty plus interest shall become immediately due and payable.
requirements.quoted_text: B. In the event of any default in payment, which default continues for ten (10) business days beyond the due date of payment, the entire unpaid penalty, together with interest, as computed pursuant to 28 U.S.C. § 1961, from the date of default to the date of payment, shall immediately become due and payable;

requirements.description: The civil penalty judgment is not subject to discharge under the Bankruptcy Code, and the facts alleged in the complaint shall be taken as true in any subsequent enforcement litigation.
requirements.quoted_text: C. This judgment represents a civil penalty owed to the United States Government and is not compensation for actual pecuniary loss, and, therefore, it is not subject to discharge under the Bankruptcy Code pursuant to 11 U.S.C. § 523(a)(7). Defendant agrees that the facts as alleged in the complaint filed in this action shall Page 3 of 14 be taken as true, without further proof, in any subsequent litigation filed by or on behalf of the Commission to collect any unpaid amount or otherwise enforce its rights pursuant to this Order.

requirements.description: Proceedings under this Part are in addition to, and not in lieu of, any other civil or criminal penalties or enforcement proceedings.
requirements.quoted_text: D. Proceedings initiated under this Part are in addition to, and not in lieu of, any other civil or criminal penalties that may be provided by law, including any other proceedings Plaintiff may initiate to enforce this Order.

requirements.description: Defendant relinquishes all dominion, control, and title to the funds paid and shall make no claim to or demand return of the funds.
requirements.quoted_text: E. Defendant relinquishes all dominion, control, and title to the funds paid to the fullest extent permitted by law. Defendant shall make no claim to or demand return of the funds, directly or indirectly, through counsel or otherwise.

provisions.title: Prohibited Business Activities
provisions.summary: Defendant is permanently restrained from failing to provide required FCRA pre-adverse action and post-adverse action notices to consumers, and from otherwise failing to comply with FCRA Sections 604 and 615.

requirements.description: When using a consumer report for employment purposes, Defendant is prohibited from failing to provide the consumer, before taking adverse action, (1) a copy of the consumer report and (2) a written description of the consumer's FCRA rights, as required by FCRA Section 604(b)(3).
requirements.quoted_text: A. When using a consumer report for employment purposes, failing to provide a consumer to whom the consumer report relates, before taking adverse action against the consumer based in whole or in part on information contained in the consumer report, (1) a copy of the consumer report, and (2) a description in writing of the consumer’s rights under the FCRA, as required by Section 604(b)(3) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681b(b)(3);

requirements.description: After taking adverse action based on a consumer report, Defendant is prohibited from failing to provide the consumer: (1) notice of the adverse action; (2) the consumer reporting agency's name, address, and telephone number; (3) a statement that the agency did not make the adverse action decision; and (4) notice of the consumer's right to a free copy of the report and to dispute its accuracy, as required by FCRA Section 615(a).
requirements.quoted_text: B. After taking adverse action against a consumer based in whole or in part on information contained in a consumer report, failing to provide to the consumer: (1) notice of the adverse action taken; (2) the name, address, and telephone number of the consumer reporting agency (including a toll-free telephone number established by the agency if the agency compiles and maintains files on consumers on a nationwide basis) from which the consumer report was obtained; (3) a statement that the consumer reporting agency did not make the decision to take the adverse action and is unable to provide the consumer the specific reasons why the adverse action was taken; and (4) notice of the consumer’s right (A) to obtain, under Section 612 of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681j, within 60 days after receiving notice of the adverse action, a free copy of the consumer report from the consumer reporting agency from which the report was obtained, and (B) to dispute, under Section 611 of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681i, with a consumer reporting agency the accuracy or completeness of any information in a consumer report furnished by the agency, as required by Section 615(a) of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. § 1681m(a);

requirements.description: Defendant is prohibited from failing to otherwise comply with Sections 604 and 615 of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681b and 1681m, as amended.
requirements.quoted_text: C. Failing otherwise to comply with Sections 604 and 615 of the FCRA, 15 U.S.C. §§ 1681b and 1681m, as they may be amended from time to time.

provisions.title: Compliance Monitoring
provisions.summary: Defendant must cooperate with FTC monitoring, including submitting reports, producing documents, appearing for deposition, and providing access to business locations upon written notice; the Commission may also use lawful investigative means including undercover posing as a consumer.

requirements.description: Within ten (10) days of receipt of written notice from a Commission representative, Defendant shall submit additional written reports (sworn under penalty of perjury), produce documents for inspection and copying, appear for deposition, and/or provide entry to any business location during normal business hours.
requirements.quoted_text: A. Within ten (10) days of receipt of written notice from a representative of the Commission, Defendant shall submit additional written reports, which are true and accurate and sworn to under penalty of perjury; produce documents for inspection and copying; appear for deposition; and/or provide entry during normal business hours to any business location in Defendant’s possession or direct or indirect control to inspect the business operation;

requirements.description: The Commission is authorized to use all other lawful means, including obtaining discovery from any person under the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure and posing as a consumer to Defendant or its employees without prior identification or notice.
requirements.quoted_text: B. In addition, the Commission is authorized to use all other lawful means, including but not limited to: 1. obtaining discovery from any person, without further leave of court, using the procedures prescribed by Fed. R. Civ. P. 30, 31, 33, 34, 36, 45, and 69; 2. posing as consumer to Defendant, its employees, or another other entity managed or controlled in whole or in part by Defendant, without the necessity of identification or prior notice; and

requirements.description: Defendant shall permit Commission representatives to interview any employer, consultant, independent contractor, representative, agent, or employee who has agreed to such an interview regarding any conduct subject to this Order.
requirements.quoted_text: C. Defendant shall permit representatives of the Commission to interview any employer, consultant, independent contractor, representative, agent, or employee who has agreed to such an interview, relating in any way to any conduct subject to this Order. The person interviewed may have counsel present.

provisions.title: Compliance Reporting
provisions.summary: For five years, Defendant must notify the FTC of structural changes at least 30 days in advance, file annual written compliance reports (beginning 180 days after entry), notify the FTC of any bankruptcy filing within 15 days, and submit all reports by overnight courier or first-class mail with electronic copy.

requirements.description: For five (5) years from entry of the Order, Defendant shall notify the Commission of any changes in its structure or any business entity it controls or has an ownership interest in that may affect compliance obligations, at least thirty (30) days prior to such change (or as soon as practicable if less than 30 days' notice is possible).
requirements.quoted_text: A. For a period of five (5) years from the date of entry of this Order, Defendant shall notify the Commission of any changes in structure of Defendant or any business entity that Defendant directly or indirectly controls, or has an ownership interest in, that may affect compliance obligations arising under this Order, including but not limited to: incorporation or other organization; a dissolution, assignment, sale, merger, or other action; the creation or dissolution of a subsidiary, parent, or affiliate that engages in any acts or practices subject to this Order; or a change in the business name or address, at least thirty (30) days prior to such change, provided that, with respect to any proposed change in the business entity about which Defendant learns less than thirty (30) days prior to the date such action is to take place, Defendant shall notify the Commission as soon as is practicable after obtaining such knowledge.
requirements.deadline: 30 days prior to change; ongoing for 5 years

requirements.description: One hundred eighty (180) days after entry of the Order, and annually thereafter for five (5) years, Defendant shall provide a written compliance report to the FTC, sworn under penalty of perjury, detailing the manner and form of compliance with the Order, including copies of acknowledgments obtained under the Distribution of Order section and any changes reported under Subsection A.
requirements.quoted_text: B. One hundred eighty (180) days after the date of entry of this Order and annually thereafter for a period of five (5) years, Defendant shall provide a written report to the FTC, which is true and accurate and sworn to under penalty of perjury, setting forth in detail the manner and form in which it has complied and is complying with this Order. This report shall include, but not be limited to: 1. A copy of each acknowledgment of receipt of this Order, obtained pursuant to the Section titled “Distribution of Order;” and Page 7 of 14 2. Any other changes required to be reported under Subsection A of this Section.

requirements.description: Defendant shall notify the Commission within fifteen (15) days of filing any bankruptcy petition.
requirements.quoted_text: C. Defendant shall notify the Commission of the filing of a bankruptcy petition by Defendant within fifteen (15) days of filing.

requirements.description: Defendant shall send all required reports and notifications to the FTC Associate Director for Enforcement by overnight courier (or first-class mail with simultaneous electronic copy to DEBrief@ftc.gov) at the specified address.
requirements.quoted_text: D. For the purposes of this Order, Defendant shall, unless otherwise directed by the Commission’s authorized representatives, send by overnight courier all reports and notifications required by this Order to the Commission, to the following address: Associate Director for Enforcement Federal Trade Commission 600 Pennsylvania Avenue, N.W., Room NJ-2122 Washington, DC 20580 RE: FTC v. Quality Terminal Services LLC Provided, that, in lieu of overnight courier, Defendant may send such reports or notifications by first-class mail, but only if Defendant contemporaneously sends an electronic version of such report or notification to the Commission at: DEBrief@ftc.gov.

requirements.description: For compliance reporting and monitoring purposes, the Commission is authorized to communicate directly with Defendant.
requirements.quoted_text: E. For purposes of the compliance reporting and monitoring required by this Order, the Commission is authorized to communicate directly with Defendant. Provided, however, nothing in this provision shall limit the Commission’s authority to pose as a consumer or supplier pursuant to Subsection B.2 of the Section titled “Compliance Monitoring.”

provisions.title: Record Keeping Provisions
provisions.summary: For eight years from entry of the Order, Defendant must create and retain specified records relating to FCRA disclosures, consumer complaints, training materials, law enforcement communications, and all documents demonstrating full compliance with the Order.

requirements.description: For eight (8) years from entry of the Order, Defendant shall create and retain files containing names, addresses, telephone numbers, all FCRA Section 604(b)(2) disclosures and authorizations, and all materials provided to consumers in connection with compliance with FCRA Sections 604(b)(3) and 615(a).
requirements.quoted_text: A. For a period of eight (8) years from the date of entry of this Order, Defendant and its agents, employees, officers, corporations, and those persons in active concert or participation with it who receive actual notice of this Order by personal service or otherwise, are hereby restrained and enjoined from failing to create and/or retain the following records: 1. Files containing the names, addresses, telephone numbers, all disclosures and authorizations made pursuant to Section 604(b)(2) of the FCRA, and all materials provided to consumers by Defendant in connection with its compliance with Sections 604(b)(3) and 615(a) of the FCRA.

requirements.description: For eight (8) years, Defendant shall retain consumer complaints (in any form, received directly or indirectly) and any responses to those complaints relating to activities alleged in the Complaint and compliance with this Order.
requirements.quoted_text: 2. Consumer complaints (whether received in written or electronic form, directly, indirectly, or through any third party), and any responses to those complaints, whether in written or electronic form, that relate to Defendant’s activities as alleged in the Complaint and Defendant’s compliance with the provisions of this Order.

requirements.description: For eight (8) years, Defendant shall retain copies of all training materials relating to activities alleged in the Complaint and compliance with this Order.
requirements.quoted_text: 3. Copies of all training materials that relate to Defendant’s activities as alleged in the Complaint and Defendant’s compliance with the provisions of this Order.

requirements.description: For eight (8) years, Defendant shall retain copies of all subpoenas and other communications with law enforcement entities or personnel that bear in any respect on Defendant's use of consumer reports for employment purposes.
requirements.quoted_text: 4. Copies of all subpoenas and other communications with law enforcement entities or personnel, whether in written or electronic form, if such documents bear in any respect on Defendant’s use of consumer reports for employment purposes.

requirements.description: For eight (8) years, Defendant shall retain all records and documents necessary to demonstrate full compliance with each provision of this Order, including copies of acknowledgments of receipt and all reports submitted to the FTC.
requirements.quoted_text: 5. All records and documents necessary to demonstrate full compliance with each provision of this Order, including but not limited to, copies of acknowledgments of receipt of this Order, required by the Sections titled “Distribution of Order” and “Acknowledgement of Receipt of Order” and all reports sumitted to the FTC pursuant to the Section titled “Compliance Reporting.”

provisions.title: Distribution of Order
provisions.summary: For five years from service of the Order, Defendant must deliver copies of the Order to all principals, officers, managers, relevant employees, and any successor business entities, and obtain signed, dated acknowledgments of receipt within 30 days of delivery.

requirements.description: For five (5) years from service of the Order, Defendant must deliver a copy of the Order to: (1) all principals, officers, directors, and managers; (2) all employees, agents, and representatives engaged in conduct related to the Order; and (3) any successor business entity. Delivery to current personnel shall occur within five (5) days of service; to new personnel prior to assuming responsibilities; and to successor entities at least ten (10) days before the structural change.
requirements.quoted_text: A. Defendant must deliver a copy of this Order to (1) all of its principals, officers, directors, and managers; (2) all of its employees, agents, and representatives who engage in conduct related to the subject matter of the Order; and (3) any business entity resulting from any change in structure set forth in Subsection A of the Section titled “Compliance Reporting.” For current personnel, delivery shall be within five (5) days of service of this Order upon Defendant. For new personnel, delivery shall occur prior to them assuming their responsibilities. For any business entity resulting from any change in structure set forth in Subsection A of the Section titled “Compliance Reporting,” delivery shall be at least ten (10) days prior to the change in structure.
requirements.deadline: 5 days for current personnel; prior to start for new personnel; 10 days before structural change

requirements.description: Defendant must secure a signed and dated acknowledgment of receipt of the Order from all persons receiving a copy, within thirty (30) days of delivery.
requirements.quoted_text: B. Defendant must secure a signed and dated statement acknowledging receipt of the Order, within thirty (30) days of delivery, from all persons receiving a copy of the Order pursuant to this Section.

provisions.title: Acknowledgment of Receipt of Order
provisions.summary: Defendant must submit a truthful sworn statement to the Commission acknowledging receipt of the Order within five business days of receipt.

requirements.description: Within five (5) business days of receipt of this Order as entered by the Court, Defendant must submit to the Commission a truthful sworn statement acknowledging receipt of the Order.
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Defendant, within five (5) business days of receipt of this Order as entered by the Court, must submit to the Commission a truthful sworn statement acknowledging receipt of this Order.

provisions.title: Retention of Jurisdiction
provisions.summary: The Court retains jurisdiction over this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of the Order.

requirements.description: The Court shall retain jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that this Court shall retain jurisdiction of this matter for purposes of construction, modification, and enforcement of this Order.

provisions.title: Costs and Attorneys' Fees
provisions.summary: Each party shall bear its own costs and attorneys' fees incurred in connection with this action.

requirements.description: Each party shall bear its own costs and attorneys' fees incurred in connection with this action.
requirements.quoted_text: IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that each party shall bear its own costs and attorneys’ fees incurred in connection with this action.

duration.termination_text: This Order does not contain an explicit termination clause. The permanent injunction (Section II) is permanent in nature. Compliance reporting obligations run for five (5) years; recordkeeping obligations run for eight (8) years from the date of entry of this Order. The Court retains jurisdiction indefinitely per Section VIII.
